repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Early Childhood Education and
            Development Project (ECED)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Early Childhood
            Education and Development Project (ECED) for Indonesia were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the parallel financing provided by the Royal
            Netherlands Government allowed the project implementation
            team to hire needed technical assistance prior to signing
            and effectiveness. This ensured that people were in place to
            support critical project components when the project became
            effective. Moreover, the block grants could also begin right
            as the project became effective so that villages could begin
            their ECED programs quickly. The Project's
            interventions were provided in a package that included
            facilitation, block grants (for operation) and teacher
            training that proved to be very effective. Moreover, each
            village group received facilitation under the Project during
            three years, long enough for them to be made aware of the
            ECED services. This period was important to generate demand
            for ECED at the village level and also to build ownership by
            the local population by providing incentives for them to
            establish and operate ECED centers. Together, these design
            features were important for obtaining positive achievements
            and to ensure sustainability at the community and district levels.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Early Child Education and
            Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Early
            Child Education and Development Project (ECED) for Indonesia
            is to improve poor children's overall development and
            readiness for further education, within a sustainable
            quality ECED system.  The project is rated
            'satisfactory' on both project development
            objectives (PDO) and implementation progress. Most of the
            performance indicators have been met, and in some instances
            targets have even been exceeded. Nearly 6,000 target
            community-managed ECED centers have been funded and are
            operational, providing services to children ages 0-6 years
            old. More than 497,000 children (mostly 3-6 years old) have
            now enrolled in these services. A parenting program will be
            introduced this year to increase immediate benefits to
            younger children and to prepare those children for later
            successful participation in ECED centers. Another notable
            progress at the community level is the functioning of a
            community-based monitoring team (TPP) which had been idle in
            previous years. Their active role in conducting annual
            assessments to ECED centers now strengthens community
            accountability and sustainability.

Indonesia - Early Child Education
            and Development Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
A snapshot of early childhood development
            in Indonesia

abstracts.cdata!:
The community-based Early Childhood
            Education and Development (ECED) program with the Ministry
            of National Education (MoNE) aims to reach 738,000 children
            in 50 districts over five years, providing block grants to
            communities whose residents decide how best to deliver early
            childhood services. In an effort to understand whether the
            program is improving children's development and
            readiness for primary school, and what factors contribute to
            effectiveness of ECED services, MoNE is undertaking an
            impact evaluation that tracks over 6,400 children (ages 1
            and 4) for a period of three years. The baseline results
            summarized here are the first to show relationships between
            parental education, nutrition, and stimulating learning
            environments and child developmental outcomes in Indonesia.

docna.cdata!: A snapshot of early childhood development in Indonesia

A snapshot of early childhood
